content.description: The reason this crag was developed! This sheer tomahawk arete is a stunner. Start up the vertical and place a finger size piece in between the 1st and 2nd bolts. Establishing onto the Â steep arete can be a little awkward. Climb up into the crack on the left side briefly before transitioning back. Then it's on for 5 bolts. Slap garbage holds on the left, grab better holds on the right. Once the last redpoint crux is passed it's another 3 bolts of easier climbing to the anchors.
content.location: Sharp steep arete with a golden west face.

content.description: A slightly overhanging face that climbs up many rails and edges. Fairly sustained all the way up to the crux below the anchors. Start as for the Bearcat Crack, placing a medium sized cam to start, then step right around the corner into a dihedral and follow the bolts. At the second to last bolt, traverse out right to the arete.
content.protection: 9? bolts   Bolted anchor with carabiners to lower
content.location: Right most route in the large alcove. Climbs the streaked wall.

content.description: Excellent varying hand crack with some tricky roof pulls up high. Still dirty, hasn't seen much traffic, and likely won't. But is definitely worthy. Reminiscent of Raspberry Rocks.I heard Zach Nix and partner may have climbed this? Or perhaps someone earlier?
content.protection: Single rack; small-large (extra medium sizes)   Bolted chain anchor
content.location: Crack on the right side of the alcove, in the left facing corner. Has a few bulges up higher.

content.description: Remote and steep. Northwest facing. A couple hard sport lines and some nice trad lines as well.
